review.title: A Logic Programming Approach to Integration Network Inference
review.abstract: The discovery, representation and reconstruction of (technical) integration networks from Network Mining (NM) raw data is a difficult problem for enterprises. This is due to large and complex IT landscapes within and across enterprise boundaries, heterogeneous technology stacks, and fragmented data. To remain competitive, visibility into the enterprise and partner IT networks on different, interrelated abstraction levels is desirable.

sections.heading: 3 Design Principles and Decisions
sections.text: The most important design decisions that were made were to seek representation for an integration model and language to formulate conclusions. We had to take (1) an approach that does not require any system change when we change the inference programs or the integration model, (2) an easy-to-understand representation of information suitable for the inference approach, and (3) a sufficiently powerful inference technique that is simple enough to be used by our customers and partners to define their own inference programs. The need for (1) derives from the development of the inference programs in the early prototypes. The range of data and scope of conclusions evolved - and will continue to evolve - as more data sources are integrated and conclusions are refined. Therefore, the life cycle of the data model and inference programs must be decoupled from that of the system. sections.heading: 7 Related Work
sections.text: Our approach to the representation and conclusion of integration networks is based on Datalog, a well-researched topic [12,25] that has recently been revived due to good parallelization capabilities, at the latest through the work of Hellerstein et al. [2,14]. Even in the field of business analysis, Datalog has recently been used, mainly through the work of [5,6,7]. However, these approaches do not address network-specific inference domains for which they define extensions. In terms of the metamodel for integration networks, [23] the closest known related work is that defines a path array used to traverse arbitrary graphs. Likewise, we define nodes and edges with incoming and outgoing connectors as different in terms of meaning and usage. For NM systems in general, related work is performed in the area of Process Mining (PM) initiated by [1], which is located between computational data mining and data intelligence.

sections.heading: 8 Discussion and Future Work
sections.text: In this paper, we present a new domain for information discovery, machine learning, and network reconstruction, for which we have defined a modeling and inference approach to reconstructing integration networks from raw NM data using Datalog. Designed specifically for connectivity and integration domains, the network model includes an intersection of relevant entities created by analyzing multiple middleware systems on the market. We encoded the raw data discovered as database facts to create a domain-independent knowledge base and apply rule-based conclusions that represent a multi-level network inference approach. We validated our approach in a simulated integration network and reported on our experiments in applying our system to enterprise networks in the real world. The evaluation shows good results in terms of challenges such as equivalence class determination, flow and cross-middleware network reconstruction, as introduced in Section 2. metadata.abstractText: The discovery, representation and reconstruction of (technical) integration networks from Network Mining (NM) raw data is a difficult problem for enterprises. This is due to large and complex IT landscapes within and across enterprise boundaries, heterogeneous technology stacks, and fragmented data. To remain competitive, visibility into the enterprise and partner IT networks on different, interrelated abstraction levels is desirable. We present an approach to represent and reconstruct the integration networks from NM raw data using logic programming based on first-order logic. The raw data expressed as integration network model is represented as facts, on which rules are applied to reconstruct the network. We have built a system that is used to apply this approach to real-world enterprise landscapes and we report on our experience with this system.
